text:
Looking for some advice and helpful comments from my Julia family.
1. I am not really enjoying my postdoc as much. It mainly stems from that the fact that my advisor is non-engaging and dosn't prioritize me. I have five first author papers that are just sitting on her desk (and also obsolete since they were covid19 related, and not relevant/novel anymore). I asked her for a recommendation letter for some TT jobs I applied too, and she still hasn't written me one. There is no mentorship nor an interest in my future career. Is being a postdoc really all about being a completely independent researcher?
2. I have been looking at moving to the industry since TT job market is so bad. However, I just can not shake the feeling that it will mark me as a failure to my current colleagues. More importantly, I just can not shake the feeling that *I will consider myself a failure.* 
Are these all normal feelings? I just have to deal with this anxiety somehow right?

text:
I'm sorry you're going through this. Regarding the seeing yourself as a failure thing, that's something I also think about a lot when I think about leaving physics. Being a physicist is a really big part of my personal identity.

On the other hand, I really just don't have the same level of emotional investment in physics as I used to have, whereas I find myself being drawn a lot to computer programming (as evidenced by the inordinate amount of time I spend in this community).

My plan for now is to finish my PhD and then re-evaluate, but I'm leaning very strongly towards software development once I leave.

I'll just say you're not alone in feeling this way and it's normal. But you have to look at what career is actually best for you, rather than what career is best for your ego or self identity.

<@U6Z8377N2> just FYI, there is <#C767M3VB3|academia>, which was made for exactly this kind of thing :slightly_smiling_face:

I totally feel you. The feeling like a failure thing if you leave academia is totally relatable, but I've come to think of that culture as basically a defense mechanism - no one would put up with the extra work, extra stress, and (substantially) lower pay of academia if they weren't able to tell themselves that they were somehow better than the people who left.

Not that I'm a shining example - I'm still in academia too, though leaning further and further toward leaving. Also worth noting that everyone I know that left academica (which is most of my friends from grad school) are very happy with their choices
